knock.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to hit a door or window with your closed hand to attract the attention of the people inside
knock.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I knocked and knocked but nobody answered.
Wilson went up and knocked on the door.
We knocked at the door but there was no one there.
knock.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to hit something with a short quick action so that it moves or falls
knock.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: As I got up, I knocked a pencil out of its holder.
He knocked the knife from my hand.
At that moment, Sally knocked over her glass of wine.
She tried to knock the gun aside but she was not fast enough.
knock.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: He knocked her to the ground and kicked her.
Garry answered the door only to be knocked flying as two policemen came rushing in.
Simon could knock a man unconscious with one punch to the jaw.
knock.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to hit something with part of your body
knock.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Morse knocked his shin against a suitcase that had been left just inside the door.
She knocked her head on a stone.
knock.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to remove a wall or part of a building in order to make a bigger room or space
knock.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: We could make a bigger living space by knocking two rooms into one.
The wall between the kitchen and the dining room has been partially knocked through.
knock.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to criticize someone or their work, especially in an unfair or annoying way
knock.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: The British press always knock British winners at any sport.
‘Designer fashion is silly.’ ‘Don’t knock it; it’s an important industry.’
knock.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to kick or hit a ball somewhere
knock.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: The aim is to knock the ball into the opposing goal.
knock.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: if an engine or pipes etc are knocking, they make a noise like something hard being hit, usually because something is wrong with them
knock.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: if your heart is knocking, it is beating hard, especially because you are afraid
knock.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the sound of something hard hitting a hard surface
knock.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: a loud knock at the door
knock.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: the action of something hard hitting your body
knock.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: He got a knock on the head when he fell.
knock.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: if something knocks the price of shares, stocks etc, the price changes very quickly and unexpectedly
knock.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Talk of easing the US credit policy knocked prices higher in light trade.
Its shares were knocked by the Kuwait Investment’s Office’s decision to sell 10% of its stake.
knock.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: to make it clear that you want to join something or want help from someone
knock.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: A number of countries are knocking at the European Union’s door.
knock.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: something which suddenly makes a product fail or makes prices fall
knock.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The US is likely totake a series of knocks from discounting in the car market.
